Award.AbstractNarration:
CIF: Large: Collaborative Research: Controlled Sensing, and Distributed Signal Processing and Decision Making in Networked Systems

PIs: Demosthenis Teneketzis (Michigan) and Venugopal Veeravalli (Illinois)

Abstract:

Many modern technological systems are networked systems. Networked systems are informationally decentralized, comprise many nodes carrying disparate information, and are subject to constraints on energy, data storage and computational capabilities. This research project entails a comprehensive study of fundamental issues that arise in networked systems, pertaining to controlled sensing, distributed signal processing, and distributed decision making, whose resolution will lead to substantial improvements in network performance. The project aims at (i) improving our understanding of the role of information in sensing, signal processing and decision making for networked systems under various architectures, in controlled and distributed settings; (ii) improving our understanding of coordination of networked systems, by evaluating the performance of the different architectures; and (iii) generating novel algorithms that will lead to networked systems that exhibit superior performance over current ones. The problems underlying these objectives cannot be adequately tackled using standard approaches in signal processing or stochastic and deterministic control theory. The investigators use key tools from stochastic optimization, distributed computation, and probability theory to develop novel methodologies that address the underlying challenges.

This project has broader impact on several fronts. It provides systematic design methodologies that are essential in many modern networked systems, and in particular, in systems for environmental (e.g., soil moisture) monitoring with distributed sensors. In addition, the research output of this project is expected to be useful to NSF's NEON program, to NASA's earth science program, and to NOAA's monitoring program. The research activities are expected to have an impact on technology transfer and graduate education through course development and training of students, with a special emphasis on including women and under-represented minority students through a strong mentorship program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many modern technological systems are networked systems. Networked systems are informationally decentralized, comprise many nodes carrying disparate information, and are subject to constraints on energy, data storage and computational capabilities. The overarching goal of this research project was a comprehensive study of fundamental issues that arise in networked systems, pertaining to controlled sensing, distributed signal processing, distributed decision making, and optimization. 

Research topics explored in the project have included: (1) Controlled sensing for multi-hypothesis testing; (2) Optimal strategies for communication and remote estimation with an energy harvesting sensor; (3) Implementation of energy-efficient tracking on a sensor network testbed; (4) Controlled sensing approach to graph classification; (5) Controlled sensing for optimal search and stop; (6) Universal outlying sequence detection;(7)Adaptive sequential stochastic optimization and learning; (8) Sequential sensor scheduling and estimation with limited actions; (9) Strategic decision making in sensing, communication and control; (10) Complexity of equilibrium in competitive diffusion games; (11) Convergence time of quantized consensus on various networks; (12) Game-theoretic analysis of Hegselmann-Krause dynamics; (13) Capacitated selfish resource allocation; (14) Binary-preference capacitated selfish replication and price of anarchy; (15) Dynamic games with resource-constrained players and asymmetric information; (16) Stochastic subgradient algorithms for strongly convex optimization over distributed networks; (17) Team-optimal distributed MMSE estimation in general and tree networks; (18) Optimal capacity allocation to sensors for networked systems; (19) Distributed algorithms for linear algebraic equations; (20) Distributed push-sum based algorithms for optimization over directed graphs; (21) Distributed hypothesis testing over time-varying graphs.

Educational activities have included: (1) proceedings papers and presentations (including a number of invited and plenary talks) on the above research topics at IEEE CDC, IEEE ICASSP, IEEE ACC, IEEE ISIT, among other conferences and workshops; (2) invited presentations on these topics at various universities and institutions around the world, including University of California, Berkeley; University of California, Los Angeles; University of California at Santa Barbara; Carnegie Mellon University at Silicon Valley; Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing; Cornell University; Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China; University of Maryland; University of Michigan; University of Miami; University of Minnesota; Pennsylvania State University; Rutgers University; University of Texas at Austin; University of Texas at Dallas; Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; TOK in Pamukkale, Turkey; University of Southern California; University of Wisconsin; Dalian Institute of Technology, Dalian, China; Purdue University; Ohio State University; Brown University; University of Rome, Italy; Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden; University of Montreal, Montreal, Canada; and (3) development of course material for detection and estimation and convex optimization graduate courses using models and algorithms from the project. 
Collaboration activities have included: (1) PIs Nedic  and Veeravalli have collaborated on the problem of adaptive sequential stochastic optimization and learning; (2) PIs Basar and Veeravalli have collaborated on modeling and optimization of energy harvesting sensors; (3) PIs Basar and Nedic have collaborated on continuous dynamic models and discrete-time algorithms for consensus; and (4) PIs Basar, Nedic, and Veeravalli have organized invited sessions on topics related to the project at the Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control and Computing, as well as at the annual IEEE Conference on Decision and Control (CDC) from 2012 through 2016, inclusively.

This project provided a solid foundation for extensive training of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduate students participating in the research. Eight graduate students, four postdoctoral fellows, and four undergraduate students have worked on this grant over the course of the project, and they have been trained in the state-of-the-art of controlled sensing, distributed signal processing, decision making and optimization in networked systems. They have learned new mathematical and engineering tools in the course of working on this project.

The developed techniques for controlled sensing for sequential hypothesis testing are also applicable to the problem of sequential design of experiments. The algorithms for universal outlier detection in sensor networks can also be applied to the understanding of visual search in humans and animals, and fraud detection and anomaly detection in big data. The distributed algorithms developed in our work have applications in wireless networks, in data mining with privacy constraints, and in function optimization in general. The theory we have developed for strategic sensing, communication and control is applicable to a broad class of problems involving dynamic games with limited, asymmetric information among the players. Our work and results on sensor scheduling applies to other scenarios where there are natural limits on the number of decisions to make or actions to take, and where no action relays some useful information. Our work on quantized consensus and convergence analysis for various types of opinion dynamics has applications in social networks. The resource allocation games we have studied find applications in economics, such as market sharing.
